content: I comission in the army and go on active duty at the beginning of June. My lease expires in august. I plan on breaking my lease with my apartment complex at the end of april, thus getting out of may, june and july of rent. I live in florida and there is a statute specifically about this. I have 2 questions. 1. Has anyone had any problems doing this in the past? My apartment complex is not very friendy in the first place as its a college complex and they just well...arent super friendly. Also I am pretty sure they havent had to deal with this before (the complex is only 3 years old. But I figure if i go in there and act like a gentlemen I shoudnt have too much of a problem. 2.The florida statute isnt very clear about how early I can break my lease from when my orders start. I go on active duty june 7th but im trying to break the last day of april so thats like a month earlier. My commander says that as long as I have orders I essentially can break my lease whenever. What do you all say? Thanks

I go on active duty june 7th but im trying to break the last day of april so thats like a month earlier. My commander says that as long as I have orders I essentially can break my lease whenever. What do you all say? Thanks

title: Anyone have experience with breaking a lease early with an apartment complex?

content: I lived in an apartment one time. It was a one bedroom. I broke my lease, said nothing to the manager. Got a phone call at work threatening to sue me. I told the person on the other end go ahead and try. And I will sue the apartment for letting 2 girls in the upstairs above me to live in that one bedroom. I never got any more phone calls after that.
reply: I lived in an apartment one time. It was a one bedroom. I broke my lease, said nothing to the manager. Got a phone call at work threatening to sue me. I told the person on the other end go ahead and try. And I will sue the apartment for letting 2 girls in the upstairs above me to live in that one bedroom. I never got any more phone calls after that.
title: Anyone have experience with breaking a lease early with an apartment complex?

content: Does your lease have a military clause? Then all you have to do is show them a copy of your orders. If not there are 2 ways to handle it: 1. Tell them that you have to move and show them the reason why. Give them the 30 days notice - tell them they can "show" the apartment. I did it this way; I ended up paying for 1 month's extra rent (until they found new renters), but they also mailed me a nice referral letter afterwards. This could be important if you will be renting again (future apartment complexes will often check your references). 2. Just pack up and go. Many places are used to this - they won't usually "pursue" you (especially if you move out of state), but they might put you on a local "bad renter" or bad credit list. You won't get a good referral if you need one.
reply: Does your lease have a military clause? Then all you have to do is show them a copy of your orders. If not there are 2 ways to handle it: 1. Tell them that you have to move and show them the reason why. Give them the 30 days notice - tell them they can "show" the apartment. I did it this way; I ended up paying for 1 month's extra rent (until they found new renters), but they also mailed me a nice referral letter afterwards. This could be important if you will be renting again (future apartment complexes will often check your references). 2. Just pack up and go. Many places are used to this - they won't usually "pursue" you (especially if you move out of state), but they might put you on a local "bad renter" or bad credit list. You won't get a good referral if you need one.
title: Anyone have experience with breaking a lease early with an apartment complex?

content: Supply the Manager a written termination of your lease stipulating why you need to break the lease. Most places sould accept it. If they take you to court, and you show that you've been a good tenant, and have orders to back you up, they'ld lose. They don't want to lose $. They want to rent that apt. Seeing that it's a college type residents. They'll have it rented in no time. Look up your states Landlord tenant laws also. Most states have them available for download online. Good Luck with it. FYI, if the MGR wants to be a harda$$ about it, go to the owner directly. They can be easier to reason with. I had to do just that at Ft Campbell.
reply: Supply the Manager a written termination of your lease stipulating why you need to break the lease. Most places sould accept it.
